pros: -few amazing coworkers who care about the community -it feels fulfilling to serve an underserved community -8% of salary in retirement -some fertility benefits but I still had to pay 5k out of pocket for one egg freezing cycle -generous vacation time that amounts to 7.5 weeks if you work a 3 day schedule
cons: -Chronically understaffed on purpose. Even when someone gives notice of quitting 8 months in advance they refuse to hire a replacement until after that person has left the position. The process to hire takes at least 4 months and the turnover rate is high so you are constantly doing the job of more than one person -floors do not have enough supplies and the hospital gives excuses as to why they cannot stock what is needed to provide patient care -Cafeteria food is unhealthy. We are a healthcare institution and should want our staff to be healthy with good food options. -ED and floors have too many patients. I’m the ED it is unsafe how many beds are stacked together to the point where you have to move 2 beds in order to access your patient in the back of the room. If something happens you are stuck back there and have a hard time getting out. Patients are admitted to the floor without a room and multiple patients live in the hallway although their insurance is charged the same amount as if they had a room. There is not enough staff to serve the amount of patients accepted to the hospital. The patients are angry and uncomfortable about their situation so instead of being able to focus on their healing, you have to listen to them complain about being stuck in the ED or hallway for days. -Employees such as transport and PCTs are hired but refuse to do work and just sit around doing nothing. Managers don’t correct the behavior so providers end up doing their job instead and get reprimanded if patients aren’t taken care of in a timely manner. When you ask this staff to help they give attitude and say they will but then don’t. -The hospital has the highest paid executives in NYC but the lowest paid PAs. Only union workers are adequately compensated so everyone is forced to unionize. No bonuses or yearly raises are given to keep up with inflation. You are overworked and underpaid. -Instead of giving money as a yearly bonus, you are given random gifts such as a cheap coffee mug or water bottle that is made from a chemical that causes cancer. -Employees who work for a hospital should get free health insurance period. I have friends who work at small law firms, in business or tech at corporations who get free health insurance yet my employer can’t provide it. That is selfishness at its core. -Not enough parking for the staff although residents are guaranteed a parking space. I’ve been on the waiting list for 3 years for a space in a community where most of the patients don’t have a car and many of the providers commute via train. I see plenty of empty spaces in the lot that could be given to staff who commute from up north because the salary is not enough to afford NYC rent. -Law firms, tech companies, banks, universities and schools cover fertility benefits 100%. It’s a myth that hospitals give good benefits as I pay more for my benefits than most of my friends from undergrad. -I frequently stay late and don’t get paid overtime. Now in order to get paid overtime the hospital wants us to clock in and out. If you clock in 15 minutes late it gets taken from your vacation time. If you stay 15 minutes late it doesn’t count as overtime. OT only starts after you’ve stayed one hour pass when your shift ends. You are punished for coming late and not rewarded for staying late even though most of the work comes in at the end of the day. The Night Shift team covers 10 surgical services so giving them too much work from 1 surgical service can be overwhelming thus you are incentivized to finish all your work from the day which requires staying late when you work on a busy understaffed service. -When someone goes on vacation on an already understaffed team, everyone is miserable. People should be allowed to take vacation. The hospital needs to be appropriately staffed. Mistakes are made when people rush or don’t have time. -ED/internal medicine is understaffed so they call inappropriate consults to work up their patients which puts extra irrelevant work on the specialty services who are also understaffed distracting us and taking time away from the patients who actually require our specialty care that only we know how to provide -clinic appointments are overbooked so not only do patients wait 6 months or more as a new patient but then when they arrive for their appointment they aren’t seen until hours later because they book multiple patients into one time slot assuming one or more will no show and don’t appropriately staff -pagers are the primary way to get in contact with other staff and it is archaic and not an effective form of communication -toxic staff who bully and degrade others are never fired because of the high turnover rate and understaffing issue -amazing staff who make the work environment a better place never stay longer than a few years because of the above issues -above all the people are who make montefiore a better place to work and provide a better experience for the patient. Invest in your staff if you care about the community and it’s workers.

review_title: Great opportunities, but politics are challenging
pros:
Giving back to the underserved.  Montefiore is in the Bronx, so you are helping people that would often normally not have access to high quality care.
Some state of the art facilities.  Certain departments have a ton of funding and therefore have the newest technologies and best of the best.
Great senior management team.  The C-level execs are top notch.  Below that, also some really bright people.  
Strong staff development curriculum.  The institution really focuses on developing its employees and retaining them as staff members increase their skill sets and learn to be more skilled clinicians and staff.  
Great benefits.
cons: Politics are rampant.  There are stories all over the place about people that got promoted inappropriately due to family connections, extramarital affairs, etc.  It's really horrifying to those of us who work hard.  There have also been innumerable instances in which people have been fired unfairly because someone powerful did not like him/her, but the person was a good worker and employee.  This was horrible for employee morale and damaged the work culture tremendously.  Similarly, favoritism in promotions.  Pay is better elsewhere (compared to other academic medical centers in the NY area).  Neighborhood is not so good (going out to lunch is not so much an option, unless you want to take a risk).

job_title: Clinical Lab Technologist in New Rochelle, NY
pros: Pros- 1199 benefits are decent. The doctors, nurses, and PAs are pleasant for the most part. Co-workers are very helpful and don't withhold information needed to do a good job.
cons:
Cons-being that this is a union hospital, new employees do get dumped on. Case in point: when it's time to provide shift coverage if one of the staff members calls out or is on vacation, the technologist with least senority ALWAYS ends up covering. I feel like coverage should be rotated so that it doesn't feel like the least senior technologist is always the one making the sacrifice to his or her time. 

Management also has problems retaining the new technologists; new technologists are in and out. Who could blame them? The pay rate is not on par with other places, the whole senority system is not exactly friendly to new technologists, and we have to sacrifice our outside life schedule because the system does not make it a requirement that the senior techs also make sacrifices. So the same people make sacrifices until they become disgruntled and end up leaving because management hasn't come up with a suitable remedy to the situation.

pros: Training was great, hands on, and I received a lot of tolerance if it took me longer than usual to learn.  The benefits are great but very hard to understand, and at times you have to be following up with their billing process.  Amazing people to work with and if you keep an open mind, every department can be a productive place to work in.  Their technology is improving and that is an amazing process.
cons: Management recruitment needs to be updated, positions have been held by the same people for the past decades.  People tend to get a little too comfortable.  The procedures need to be redefined, and be reflective for the society we live in, a society in which technology is more relevant and it can simplify basic tasks.

pros: Union benefits when you qualify, awesome co-workers, great benefits like programs that allow you to get discounted tickets for sports events and Broadway shows. Also programs that allow you to pay for electronics and furnishings on installments.
cons: Depending on where you work the support that you get from your administrative management can be supportive or can be completely unsupportive. I worked at an outpatient clinic in the Bronx and as an LPN I strongly felt like I had no ability to go up the career ladder. There was minimal opportunities for me to get my RN degree so I was forced to leave. This was an issue that I had brought up with the president of the outpatient facilities for months prior to my departure. I bothered him like three times and unfortunately my complaints fell on deaf ears. Additionally where you work, depending on how they work your schedule it can be quite difficult to attend school - just a forewarning.

pros: Patient care is sometimes very good.  When I was hired at Monte, they did have an a very generic on-boarding process for new employees, I did not have to trained on much since I my skill-sets were already transferable.  I love what I do but I am grossly under paid for the volume of work I do, therefore, makes my life unbalanced.  All of this has been ignored and has fallen on deaf ears.  As long as the work gets done the managers do not care.
cons: The culture of not paying attention to how hard Administrative Office Supervisors work.  Office politics is very prevalent within Montefiore.  It is all about who you know at Montefiore.

pros: The best thing about working there is having the opportunity to meet new people and possibly network.  Starting out as a customer service liaison can lead to a dead end fast if you do not meet someone high up on the food chain.
cons: The superiors feed you tons of crap saying things like "you can make it far if you apply yourself," but after you have a conversation with a few of the other liaison's that have been there for years and are still in the same position you will beg to differ.  That position is basically a gateway position to get your feet wet considering how hard it is to get inside Montefiore period if you're not some type of doctor with an extensive educational background.

pros: The people overall are great to work with.  The 4x10 shift is nice--particularly having 3 days off.
cons: Senior leadership is corrupt, backstabbing, completely dysfunctional and enormous hypocrites.  Dealing with them on a regular basis makes working at Montefiore feel like a prison sentence.

pros: Working in the emergency department there is a great sense of teamwork amongst all staff. This is the only reason most PA's decide to stay.
cons: where to start- Montefiore pays the patient care techs, nurses, secretaries and attending physicians pretty well, but not the PA's. Across all the Montefiore hospitals what they do is hire new grads at a competitive rate and then never raise the salary- at the HR briefing when you are hired they talk about merit based pay in addition to your raise, but dont count on either happening. When you do get a raise, its not even consistent with a cost of living raise. I love seeing the new billboards they have along the highway that say "Doing More-Montefiore"- what a joke. Every PA that leaves Monte gets a serious pay increase. Its a shame too because they constantly are losing well trained PA's. Needless to say I wont be sticking around much longer.

pros: Good benefits, many educational trainings. Montefiore is a company that is deep rooted in the community and its relentless in its efforts to make it better. Their drive to achieve ways to provide quality healthcare pushes them constantly to find ways of improvement not only on medical services but also providing employees with appropriate training to achieve those improvements. Solid company.  Good president and VPs that care for the community.
cons: Expensive healthcare benefits. Lots of diversity not enough inclusion.  Good training not enough recognition.

pros: great healthcare benefits through 1199
cons: Micromanaged, no room for growth, managers show too much favoritism, management not willing to develop employees, always focusing on what your doing wrong and never encouraged when doing a good job unless a patient calls to give a commendation.  Managers don't really talk with CSL's unless it's to correct or tell what to do. No kind of compassion when dealing with personal/family issues and no wok-life balance  Always have to fight for time off. Creates discord among colleagues due to favoritism.  Level move based on numbers only and not quality of handling call and based on if they like you.  Upper level management rarely allows you to meet with them unless you are being disciplined.  No open door policy to speak to upper level management. If trying to move around in organization, your overlooked because the policy is to hire the more senior person and will overlook a more qualified person due to seniority.  CMO only promotes people in their click and who is friend upper level management.

pros: * None of any real significance
cons:
* Many poorly trained staff/inadequate supervision resulting in poor quality care
* Focus is on volume and not quality care
* Low pay and mediocre benefits
* Too many overpaid managers / managers who spend their time in their offices
* Some arrogant MDs undermine teamwork
* Non-MDs treated like factory workers (ex. have to punch in and out/not treated like professionals)
* Absolutely horrible parking situation at main hospital for staff that commute by car

pros: Benefits are good my insurance is covered through 1199 National Benefit Fund.
cons: I've worked for Montefiore for 11 years at 3 various locations. I have worked my way up very slowly by transferring to different locations. One thing that many sites have in common is a lack of poor management there is no such thing here as experience and education is all about who you know. Out of the 3 sites there was 1 administrator that was fantastic but unfortunately no room for growth so I was forced to move on.

pros: Great company to work for. I see alot of people who have been here for years so there's longevity.
cons:
Benefits are not so great.  The medical costs alot especially if you have a family. The only good thing is that they match up to 8% after your first year. 
Some managers are really not good leaders. Not everyone is meant to be a leader and it shows with more than a few managers here.
They say that they are all for growth but it is not encouraged here. Instead when you express interest you get torn down.
The pay depends on the department and how much they are willing to pay for a good candidate. I think there is some bias there.

job_title: LMSW Care Manager in Bronx, NY
pros: Great benefits. The salary is decent for a social worker in general. A lot of vacation time. Co-workers are great for the most part. Once here for a year you can apply for different positions within Montefiore and are considered first for the position.  Small yearly bonus.
cons: Steadily increase of  case load with more high needs clinets. High turnover rates. Not enough pay to deal with the increasing amount of work associated with  amount of case management needed to stabilize patients lives. Managers and Managed Care Plans have high expectations to get things done  very quickly which is not realistic.

pros: Montefiore is a large, complex organization with broad reach of services, research, education, and advocacy activities.  Because of this working here can be very impactful and rewarding.  Montefiore serves the Bronx which needs a lot of help and Montefiore is committed to working closely with the community, to training and hiring people from the community.
cons: Because of the Pros above Montefiore is a large, complex organization with broad reach of services, research, education, and advocacy activities.  This size can be frustrating and difficult to manage and things sometimes don't get done in a reasonable time frame.  Sometimes the institution makes decisions that are not always in the best interests of the people who work here.

review_title: You must be a curtain type of person to enjoy working here.
pros: Great Benefits. Lots of paid vacation time. Some people are actually really friendly and welcoming.
cons: More people with a chip on their shoulder than I've ever seen in one place. Hard to work with others. Lots of "passing the buck" as far as trying to get others to do their job for them. Little praise for job well done. No clear expectations for job duties.

pros: Staff and physicians are dedicated and caring. However, these values are not supported by management.
cons: Lacks leadership in this particular clinic to improve morale and provide support to the doctors so doctors can provide quality care without having to be concerned about supply and sanitary condition and daily function of the clinic. Certain staff had found it useful to socialize with management in order to be on their good side. The staff member ,who remained hard-working and believed in providing quality care ,has felt threatened by management. Management more concerned about power.

pros: Salary, benefits, tuition reimbursement.  Convenient location. Serves a diverse community.
cons: Far behind in many healthcare initiatives.  Difficult to implement change.  Poor safety culture.  Outdated equipment and infrastructure.  Senior nursing leadership lack vision and ability to improve nursing practice within organization.  Many longtime RN employees leading to complacency, resistance to change and often hostile to new employees.  Union atmosphere diminishes professionalism and personal accountability.  Peer to peer bullying is rampant with little or no efforts by management to address this problem. Difficult to be a change agent in this organization.  HR does little to support staff that are victims of workplace bullying.

pros: Good benefits, time-off (although less than Einstein), good location.
cons: People talk about opportunities, but for lower level employees there isn't a lot of incentive or opportunity to move up. A boss cannot give merit-based raises, which is discouraging. This doesn't promote an environment where an employee would be willing to go above and beyond, unless for their own self-satisfaction. School is not encouraged as is reported by the institution and is not fully-reimbursed.

review_title: Opportunity to make a huge impact on children's lives

review_title: Tried to stay longer but nope...

And a lot of them were very catty and talked a lot of smack behind each other's back. Plus my manager wasn't that great either but that's just MY opinion. I just had to go.

review_title: Montefiore IT: Be careful, they will lie to you at every turn.
pros: Free lunch and learns every once in a while.
cons:
1.) Absolutely no one is applying to positions here and as a result hiring managers tell massive lies in order to get people in the door.  The job title you apply for is rarely what you're actually doing.

2.) Technical decisions are made by business and it shows.  No one on the tech side seems to be qualified or even willing to keep business out of making technical decisions.  The tech stack in nearly every department is a huge tangled mess of various technologies that aren't documented, are poorly coded, extremely fragile and maintained by people who don't really understand how they work.  Technical decision making is almost laughably bad, there is a new project called EPIC being implemented and in the rush to get it implemented as quickly as possible project managers are being asked to purchase hardware for projects without having any software resource requirements or customer usage patterns to work off of.

3.) A large number of employees are embarrassingly unqualified for their jobs.  In my short time there I ran into "project managers" who didn't know what a software development life cycle was.  "Technical Leads" who were utterly confused by talk of simple data structures like stacks and queues being used in the very code they were in charge of. "Software Engineers" who didn't understand what looping structures were.

4.) As a result of #3 entrenched employees do everything they can to push out anyone they see is actually qualified.  During my training, and I use the word training loosely, I was purposely lied to about how certain applications were supposed to work.  After a few weeks I just gave up on asking questions and simply started figuring things out on my own since I knew nothing I was told would be true.

5.) System automation is non-existent, it's considered perfectly acceptable for employees to babysit applications 24/7 when there are a multitude of free solutions for system monitoring available. 

6.) Montefiore IT employees get treated terribly in comparison to hospital and CMO employees.  If you make friends with people over at CMO and the hospital you'll quickly discover that they are treated with much more respect and have better working conditions.  Montefiore IT gets the worst of everything.

7.) The dress code is ridiculous.  They pay nearly 25% less than industry standards, which is fine because it is a non-profit.  What is not fine is that they expect you dress business casual to work.  Nearly every other company is jeans and t-shirt and will pay you more money.

8.) The insurance plan was recently changed and it is a disaster if you don't live near the Bronx.  Medical care is free if you go to a Montefiore clinic or hospital but there are two huge problems.  It's extremely difficult to get an appointment, the wait time is nearly 5 weeks in most cases and if you don't live close to the Bronx you have to drive very far to get there.  If you go to a non-Montefiore doctor, good luck,  I've paid more money in the past few months in medical fees than I have ever paid during my time at all of my previous jobs combined.

9.) Basic things like having your computer setup so you can work properly are not taken care of.  You won't have the ability to get your work done properly because you won't get all of the tools you need to do your job.

10.) I watched people who were highly qualified get fed up and quit several times in my short span of employment.
